titlestmt.title: Moore & Co's Advertisement Copy 1: electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 17KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 177KB to 1600KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesNovember 2019
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of nineteen separate prints designed and etched or engraved by Blake. The original works are housed in seven collections, including the Bodleian Library, British Museum, Robert N. Essick collection, Fitzwilliam Museum, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and National Gallery of Art, Washington. These separate prints join two others, Deaths Door and George Cumberland’s Card, and four series of prints, all previously published, to complete this important category of Blake's endeavors as a printmaker.
The new group of nineteen includes Blake’s first separate engraving, Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, executed while still an apprentice, and two of his masterpieces in mixed-method etching/engraving, the large Job and Ezekiel plates. The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder, Lucifer and the Pope in Hell, and Albion rose depict Blake's response to the political revolutions of the late eighteenth century. Blake printed these three, plus A Dream of Thiralatha and Joseph of Arimathea Preaching to the Inhabitants of Britain, in colors as part of his development of relief and planographic color printing in the mid-1790s. Other plates, ranging from The Approach of Doom to the Enoch lithograph and The Chaining of Orc, testify to Blake's lifelong experimentation with innovative graphic techniques. He produced Deaths Door and the Virgil Relief Etching as book illustrations but they were never published as such and exist only as unique, separate impressions. Introductions to each work offer information on medium, changes in state, dating, and subject. Blake’s Laocoön etching/engraving, sometimes considered a separate plate, is included among the Illuminated Books in the Archive.
Late in his career, c. 1820-25 or even extending into his final year, Blake returned to several of his earlier separate engravings, dramatically revising the interplay of darkness and light in their designs and adding new inscriptions on some plates that alter their meaning. These final states of Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, Job, Ezekiel, The Accusers, Albion rose, and Blake's largest and most ambitious print, Chaucers Canterbury Pilgrims, are included, along with extant earlier states. The publication of these and other multiple states and printings offer insights into Blake's development as a printmaker and changes in his thematic interests over several decades.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blakeinventor, delineator, etcher, engraver. Blake designed only the portion of the image below the clouds at the top. He engraved all the pictorial motifs.

anonymousengraver. The inscriptions between the columns and the quotation from Martial below the design were probably engraved by an anonymous writing engraver. The references to "Loom[s]" and "Frame" and Blake's signature immediately below the design were scratched in drypoint by Blake.
anonymousprinter. Proofs of the plate may have been pulled by William and Catherine Blake, but most impressions were probably printed by a professional copperplate printer.

objinfo.platemark: 35.2 cm. vertical measurement. The left and right sides of the platemark are trimmed off in the only known impressions.
objinfo.watermark: none visibleThe backing mat to which the print is pasted prevents inspection for a watermark. According to A. G. B. Russell, *The Engravings of William Blake* (London: Grant Richards, 1912), page 57, this impression is "printed on Whatman paper," but this cannot now be confirmed.

provenance.name: British Museum

objnote.p: A preliminary sketch in the Fondazione Horne, Florence (Butlin 340 verso), shows that Blake designed all the motifs below the clouds at the top. The upper part of the drawing is defined by curving lines that suggest drapery more than clouds. Above the center are slight pencil indications of the Royal Arms clearly pictured in the engraving. This motif and the feathers (left) and coat of arms (right) of the Prince of Wales are of course not of Blake's own invention. The inscription between the columns and the quotation from Martial below the design were probably engraved by an anonymous writing engraver. The references to "Loom[s]" and "Frame" and Blake's signature immediately below the design were scratched in drypoint by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this advertisement, a central section of text is framed on either side by two columns. A horizontal area of cloudy sky extends across the top of the design while an interior room is visible below the text near the lower edge of the composition. The royal coat of arms of Britain is depicted in the center of the area of sky with beams of light extending outward from it. The royal arms includes a quartered shield flanked by a lion at left and a unicorn at right as well as a banner with text below and a crown above. To the left of and slightly below the royal arms is the heraldic badge for the Prince of Wales, the feathers. This emblem includes three feathers encircled by a crown and banner. To the right of and slightly below the royal arms is the crest of the Prince of Wales, which includes a crowned lion atop a crown with a banner below. Clouds are visible around these three emblems in the sky. The tops of both columns that flank the text are obscured by clouds. Just below the clouds, patterned textiles wrap around the columns and descend along the back side of the columns into the lower section of the design, framing both side walls of the interior space below. The bases of the columns are visible and both stand on short pedestals. Three figures are visible between the bases of the columns. The leftmost figure faces forward and turns his head to look up and right. He has short curly hair and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes. His right leg is bent and rests on the pedestal of the column. Both arms are raised to touch the edge of the textile around the column. The second figure from the left kneels facing right and bends forward, perhaps to roll a section of the textiles visible in front of him at right with his extended right arm. He has short curly hair and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes. The third, rightmost figure sits facing left on the pedestal below the right column. She has long hair and wears a gown. She bends forward with both arms extended to work with a spinning wheel beside her at left. The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. The leftmost figure is a small child or youth who stands in the lower left corner facing right. He appears to have short hair and wear a shirt and breeches. His right arm is raised horizontally and extended forward to touch the fabric of the loom at right. He appears to look up toward the second figure from the left beside him. This adult male figure stands facing away and slightly right. He has long hair pulled back in a ponytail and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes. He stands inside of a loom, which he appears to operate with both extended hands, arms bent and raised in front of his body, and perhaps also his feet, as he stands on the treadles. He leans forward slightly. The third figure from the left, who appears to be a male youth, stands facing away and turns to the left to look at the weaver. He wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes, and has short curly hair. He leans forward and raises both arms to pull or hold the ropes visible in front of him. Both legs are bent and his left leg is extended backward. The fourth figure from the left, a female figure with long hair and a gown, stands facing right and appears to talk with the fifth figure from the left, a male figure who faces forward and points to the right. The female figure's right arm is at her side while her left is raised at a right angle. The male figure wears a shirt, coat, breeches, and shoes and has short curly hair. His right arm is at his side, palm facing forward, and his left is raised horizontally as he points to the right. A large rug loom is visible in the center of the interior space and two women, who are seated facing away on a bench in front of the machine, work at the loom on what appears to be a tapestry or rug. Both women wear a hat and gown and appear to have long hair. The woman at left raises both bent arms; she grasped the fabric on the loom with her right hand and, in her left, holds a tool, perhaps a shuttle(?), near the loom. The woman at right also raises both bent arms to touch the fabric on the loom and turns to the left and down. The rightmost figure in the lower scene sits at a smaller loom facing right. He has short hair and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes. He bends forward and raises both bent arms to work at the loom.

component.illusobjdesc: A horizontal area of cloudy sky extends across the top of the design. The royal coat of arms of Britain is depicted in the center of the sky with beams of light extending outward from it. The royal arms includes a quartered shield flanked by a lion at left and a unicorn at right as well as a banner with text below and a crown above.
To the left of and slightly below the royal arms in the sky at top is the heraldic badge for the Prince of Wales, the feathers. This emblem includes three feathers encircled by a crown and banner.
To the right of and slightly below the royal arms in the sky at top is the crest of the Prince of Wales, which includes a crowned lion atop a crown with a banner below.

In this advertisement, a central section of text is framed on either side by two columns. The tops of both columns that flank the text are obscured by clouds. Just below the clouds, patterned textiles wrap around the columns and descend along the back side of the columns into the lower section of the design, framing both side walls of the interior space below. The bases of the columns are visible and both stand on short pedestals.

Three figures are visible between the bases of the columns. The leftmost figure faces forward and turns his head to look up and right. He has short curly hair and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes. He appears to be a child or youth. His right leg is bent and rests on the pedestal of the column. Both arms are raised to touch or hold the edge of the textile around the column.

Three figures are visible between the bases of the columns. The second figure from the left kneels facing right and bends forward with head down, perhaps to roll a section of the textiles visible in front of him at right with his extended right arm. He appears to be a child or youth. He has short curly hair and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes.

Three figures are visible between the bases of the columns. The third, rightmost figure sits facing left on the pedestal below the right column. She has long hair and wears a gown. She bends forward with both arms extended to work with a spinning wheel beside her at left.
A spinning wheel is visible to the left of the base of the right column. A female figure appears to spin thread using it.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. The leftmost figure is a small child or youth who stands in the lower left corner facing right. He appears to have short hair and wear a shirt and breeches. His right arm is raised horizontally and extended forward to touch the fabric of the loom at right; his left arm appears to be bent and at his side. He appears to look up toward the second figure from the left beside him.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. The second figure from the left is an adult male figure who stands facing away and slightly right. Alternatively, he may lean or sit on the board behind him that is part of the loom. He has long hair pulled back in a ponytail with a ribbon and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes. He stands inside of a loom, which he appears to operate with both hands, arms bent and raised in front of his body, and perhaps also his feet, as he stands on the treadles. He bends forward slightly.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. The third figure from the left, who appears to be a male youth, stands facing away and turns to the left to look at the weaver. He wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes, and has short curly hair. He bends forward and raises both arms to pull or hold the ropes visible in front of him. Both legs are bent and his left leg is extended backward.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. The fourth figure from the left, a female figure with long hair and a gown, stands facing right and appears to talk with the fifth figure from the left, a male figure. The female figure's right arm is at her side while her left is raised at a right angle, palm facing up. A shoe is visible beneath the hem of her gown.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. The fifth figure from the left is a male figure who wears a shirt, coat, breeches, and shoes and has short curly hair. He faces forward and slightly left as he appears to talk to the female figure at his left. His right arm is at his side, palm facing forward, and his left is raised horizontally as he points to the right.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. A large rug loom is visible in the center of the interior space and two women, who are seated facing away on a bench in front of the machine, work at the loom on what appears to be a tapestry or rug. Both women wear a hat and gown and appear to have long hair. The woman at left raises both bent arms; she grasped the fabric on the loom with her right hand and, in her left, holds a tool, perhaps a shuttle(?), near the loom.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. A large rug loom is visible in the center of the interior space and two women, who are seated facing away on a bench in front of the machine, work at the loom on what appears to be a tapestry or rug. Both women wear a hat and gown and appear to have long hair. The woman at right also raises both bent arms to touch the fabric on the loom and turns to the left and down. She may hold a tool, perhaps scissors(?), in her right hand.

The interior space at the bottom of the design contains eight figures. The rightmost figure in the lower scene sits at a smaller loom facing right. He has short hair and wears a shirt, breeches, and shoes. He bends forward and raises both bent arms to work at the loom. He may hold thread in his right hand.

Three looms occupy much of the interior space in the lower sector of the composition. Two women appear to work with tools, perhaps a shuttle(?) and scissors(?), at the central, largest loom. They may be weaving a carpet or tapestry. The floor appears to be made of wooden boards, particularly at right.

lg.l: The greatest variety of CARPETS, from the lowest Scotch,

l.hi: & Kidderminster, Wilton & Brussels, to the finest
Private Families may be supplied with Silk, Cotton,

lg.l: Worsted, and Thread STOCKINGS of all kinds & qualities,

l.hi: Colours & patterns of Carpeting may be changed to suit the taste of
the Purchaser, & patterns of Hosiery made to any size.
Common Carpet Loom Persia & Turkey Carpet Loom Stocking Frame Blake d. & sc:

l.foreign: Hœc tibi Londini tellus dat munera: victa est
l.note: "Hœc" is probably an error for "Hæc." Lines 20-21 are an adaptation from Martial which translates to "the district of London offers you these services: the needle of Babylon is already surpassed by the loom of Britain" (Essick pages 47-48).
